"Late Monday, the Data and Safety Monitoring Board (DSMB) notified NIAID, BARDA, and AstraZeneca that it was concerned by information released by AstraZeneca on initial data from its COVID-19 vaccine clinical trial. The DSMB expressed concern that AstraZeneca may have included outdated information from that trial, which may have provided an incomplete view of the efficacy data. We urge the company to work with the DSMB to review the efficacy data and ensure the most accurate, up-to-date efficacy data be made public as quickly as possible."

The FDA has granted 3 EUA's as of 03/02/21.  The EUA process from filing an application to approval by the FDA took 18 days for Moderna and 22 days for Pfizer, and J&J.  AstraZeneca and Novovax are the next two most likely companies to seek an EUA from the FDA.  The AstaZeneca vaccine has received approval from several other countries and is being widely administered in Europe, Mexico, India, Argentina, and several other countries.  However, AstraZeneca has faced problems with its data related to the efficaciousness in the elderly population and their mistakes in dosing their trials.  As a result, AstraZeneca will likely have to wait to conclude US phase 3 trials which will take a few more weeks.  Novovax's vaccine results from Britain look excellent.  Novovax will likely seek British approval in the next few weeks based on these trials conducted there.  Then, Novovax is expected to apply for US approval in the 2nd quarter of 2021 based on the British trial data (if FDA will accept it), or it will wait on US phase 3 trials to complete, which could take 2-3 more months.  It is unlikely that AstraZeneca or Novovax will receive EUA approval before 3/31/21 as that would require filing an EUA application no later than March 13, 2021, based on recent precedent.  With that said, as variants continue to spread and the decline in positive cases and hospitalizations stalls in the U.S., it is possible that a 4th vaccine could receive an EUA in the next 29 days.

Johnson & Johnson expects to release critical results from its coronavirus vaccine trial in as little as two weeks but probably won’t be able to provide as many doses this spring as it promised the federal government because of manufacturing delays. If the vaccine can strongly protect people, as some outside scientists expect, it will offer big advantages over the two vaccines authorized in the United States. Unlike those, which require two doses, Johnson & Johnson’s could need just one, greatly simplifying logistics for local health departments and clinics struggling to get shots in arms. Its vaccine can also stay stable in a refrigerator for months, whereas the others have to be frozen. But the encouraging prospect of a third effective vaccine is tempered by apparent lags in the company’s production. In the company’s $1 billion contract signed with the federal government in August, Johnson & Johnson pledged to have 12 million doses ready by the end of February, ramping up to a total of 100 million doses by the end of June. Federal officials have been told that the company has fallen as much as two months behind the original production schedule and won’t catch up until the end of April, when it was supposed to have delivered more than 60 million doses, according to two people familiar with the situation who were not authorized to discuss it publicly. Dr. Paul Stoffels, Johnson & Johnson’s chief scientific officer, said he expected to see clinical trial data showing whether the company’s vaccine is safe and effective in late January or early February. It looks like although AstraZeneca's vaccine is getting increased use globally (likely due to its ease of transportation and longer "shelf" life), the US is not keen to approve soon (https://time.com/5925495/oxford-astrazeneca-vaccine-approval/).  That leaves two other vaccines in phase 3 trials: Janssen and Novavax (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines.html). Janssen (also referred to at times by its parent company's name, Johnson & Johnson) is hoping to request emergency approval by next month. We saw things move pretty quickly with the first two vaccines once the approvals were requested, and the FDA is likely going to be extra-motivated to rule on this one because it requires only one shot and does not require super-low temperatures for storage and transportation. It looks like Novavax only started Phase III trials in the US recently (https://www.biopharma-reporter.com/Article/2021/01/04/AstraZeneca-Pfizer-Novavax-The-latest-developments-in-COVID-19-vaccines), so the clock is definitely ticking for them. Not sure they'll get in under the 31 March wire. Based on all of this, I'm even more confident we'll have 3, and even less confident we'll have 4. Janssen's not a guarantee, but things continue to look good. Astrazeneca looks very unlikely and Novavax might still pull it out, but it's less rosy than it was a month ago.

26 Dec update: —— 2 vaccines already authorized 
----Pfizer: already authorized for emergency use. Authorization occurred on 11 December and authorization was reissued on 23 Dec [1].
----Moderna: already authorized for emergency use. Authorization occurred on 18 December [1]. —— 1 more vaccine likely to be authorized by 31 March 2021:
----J&J: Phase III trial has finished enrolling participants. If trial data is positive, Operation Warp Speed expects an emergency use authorization request to be filed in late January or early February (note: these projections are usually optimistic, so perhaps mid/late Feb is a better estimate) [2]. FDA authorization would take a few weeks after such a filing. So authorization would most likely occur ~late Feb/early March. —— 1 more vaccine may be authorized by 31 March 2021:
----AstraZeneca:  U.S.-based phase III trial intended to provide clear results on efficacy (dosage issue in previous phase III trial made it so that efficacy results were confusing) has enrolled ~27k ppl of 30k participant goal, as of 23 Dec. Likely to finish enrolling remaining ~3k ppl in very near future. If trial data is positive, Operation Warp Speed expects an emergency use authorization request to be filed in late February or early March (note: these projections are usually optimistic, so perhaps mid/late March is a better estimate) [2]. FDA authorization would take a few weeks after such a filing. Prior phase III trial data indicates the vaccine is very likely to exceed FDA minimum requirement of 50% efficacy. So authorization would most likely occur ~late March/early April. — 2 more vaccines not at all likely to be authorized by 31 March 2021:
----Novavax: just now gearing up to start its Phase III trial [2].
----Sanofi: just now designing phase IIb plans [2]. [1] https://www.fda.gov/emergency-preparedness-and-response/mcm-legal-regulatory-and-policy-framework/emergency-use-authorization

According to the WHO Draft Landscape (as of 08 December2020)
https://www.who.int/publications/m/item/draft-landscape-of-covid-19-candidate-vaccines there are currently 12 Vaccines as advanced  as in a clinical stage Phase 3 (csP3) study and are highly likely to be proven safe and efficient - if at all - by March 2021. With regards to efficiency, the currently known candidates set a high standard at >90%, which will be hard to meet or surpass, and thus it will be hard for other vaccines following suit to prove value added or higher utility.
Four more vaccines are listed as currently in clinical stage Phase 2 (csP2), which renders it doubtful whether they will be ready for approval until March 2021, considering the transition between csP2 and csP3 appears to be the hardest and most time-consuming step, and there is a risk, i would guess, that at least one in five (20%) of them fails during the process. Of the 13 csP3 candidates, there are at least 7 concepts which by the name of the institute and/or the company originate in either China or India, at least in non-Western G20 nations (I'll have to investigate further).
The remaining 6 so far are
University of Oxford/AstraZeneca
Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies (based in Belgium, affiliate to Johnson & Johnson)
Novavax
Moderna/NIAID
BioNTech/Fosun Pharma/Pfizer
Medicago Inc. Several issues may restrict the number of vaccines which the FDA will approve at all, or with priority ("Fast Track designation"):
/The Novavax and Anhui Zhifei Longcom candidates base on "Protein Subunit" of the virus.
Without knowing the details, it appears to me those will come up with a lower price and a lower risk, but at the same time with a low efficacy. The viral proteins change during mutation and the formation of new viral strains. The vaccines may thus, in my understanding, simply prove ineffective to certain viral strains, and research will always lag behind the viral mutation.

I'm getting my list of potential vaccines from the NYT vaccine tracker [1]. After I'd done a bunch of elimination I noticed that [2] is a visually much better source. From Pfizer and Moderna we see that it takes 3-4 months to conduct a phase 3 trial, and another ~3 weeks to get it reviewed by the FDA. So I discard any vaccines that haven't started a phase 3 trial yet. There are 14 that have: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Janssen, CanSino, Gamaleya, Novavax, Medicago, Anhui, Sinopharm (2 vax), Sinovac, Bharat, Murdoch. One thing I noticed is missing from forecasts so far is the chance that the FDA will *revoke* the EUA from some vaccine due to side effects or whatever. The FDA does revoke EUAs sometimes. BASE RATES
I was unable to find these. We want to know what % of requested EUAs are granted historically, but the FDA website only has data on the EUAs that were granted, and none on the ones that were rejected. I wrote them an email several days ago asking for this data but never heard back. So we will have to do without them. SPECIFIC VACCINES
Pfizer & Moderna: both have finished phase 3 and have EUA reviews scheduled. Pfizer on 10 Dec 2020 and Moderna on 17 Dec 2020. Today the Pfizer vaccine was approved for use in the UK, which greatly increases the chances it will be approved in the US. Not just for its technical merits, but because for once there would be political fallout for the FDA from being too risk-averse. So let's say Pfizer & Moderna will definitely be accepted in December, but a 5% chance for each to have its EUA revoked before April 2021. (In part due to the tight timeframe.) So 95% chance each. AstraZeneca: they bungled phase 3 trials somehow and are starting a new one. In late Nov 2020 they appear to still be recruiting volunteers in the US for that. If they were the only game in town I think the FDA could give them an EUA without the new trial, but now I don't think so. So they need to have the new trial finished in late Feb 2021 so they're able to be approved in Mar 2021. Let's say a 30% chance for them. Janssen: they use a technology that is already approved and in use for other vaccines. This raises their chances. They started their phase 3 trial on 7 Sep 2020 [3] and they started counting infections on 22 Sep 2020. I think this gives them plenty of time to do everything, and it comes down to whether the vaccine works. I don't understand vaccines but there've not been reports of adverse effects for them so far, so I put their chances at 80%. I don't subtract 5% for chance of EUA revocation because it's an accepted vaccine platform. Novavax: has not started phase 3 actually [4]. 0% chance for them. Anhui, CanSino, Sinopharm (2 vax), Sinovac: Low odds here I think. Either they won't request FDA approval (they'll be sold to other countries), or the FDA won't grant it, or the FDA will drag its feet and review it last. I don't think the US will "admit defeat" and take a Chinese vaccine, even if it would make sense to do so, or at least, it won't do it so quickly. Since these are highly correlated events I consider these one vaccine with 15% chance of approval. Gamaleya: this one is Russian, so same treatment as the Chinese vaccines. Except, it's not as clear that this one works or is harmless. Also there's only one. So call it 5%. Medicago: combined phase 2/3 trials started on 19 Nov [5]. I'm not 100% sure what that means but if they had started phase 3 in Dec 2020 I would have given them 0%. So let's say 10% here. Bharat: phase 3 trial started on 25 Nov 2020 [6]. They are doing the trial in India so I think they will get to 130 infections quicker. (What is their testing capacity?) But again I'm not even sure if they are aiming to get FDA approval. Let's give them 10%. Murdoch: this one is actually weird. They started their phase 3 trial in March 2020 [7]. How can this be?? Well, they didn't actually develop a covid vaccine. Their trial is to see if the BCG vaccine (against tuberculosis) helps. This one is presumably already authorized by the FDA. If it turns out to help against covid, does it count? I'm gonna say no. So 0% here. PUTTING IT ALL TOGETHER
To recap, we have 10 separate events, whose probabilities I have judged thus: 95%, 95%, 30%, 80%, 0%, 15%, 5%, 10%, 10%, 0%. For simplicity I assume these are independent. Then a little python code calculates these odds: Zero vaccines: 0%
One vaccine: 1%
Two vaccines: 13%
Three vaccines: 44%
Four or more: 42% Throughout this exercise I've assumed that the FDA has time to evaluate however many vaccines. This isn't realistic, but I think they have time for up to five, since Moderna and Pfizer will be done already in Dec 2020. And my model only puts <1.5% chance on 6+, so I'm not gonna worry about it.
